content.description: A solid disk whose plane is parallel to the ground spins with an initial angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Three identical blocks are dropped onto the disk at locations <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>C</mtext></math>, one at a time, not necessarily in that order. Each block instantaneously sticks to the surface of the disk, slowing the disk’s rotation. A graph of the angular speed of the disk as a function of time is shown.
content.question: The blocks are now dropped in the reverse order and the final angular speed of the disk is <math alttext="omega sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. How does <math alttext="omega sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> compare to <math alttext="omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, the final angular speed shown on the graph from the initial experiment?

choices.label: <math alttext="omega sub 2 is less than omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>
<math alttext="omega sub 2 equals omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>
<math alttext="omega sub 2 is greater than omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>
